reviewText:
The Cave is an ambitious adventure game that has quite a lot going for it: Beautiful cartoonish art design. A twisted yet charming sense of humor. Quality voice work. Fun puzzles and scenarios that are interesting and just the right difficulty. Several playable characters, each one with their own unique themed level. And despite being limited to 30 FPS, the game still feels quite smooth (much less of a problem than I anticipated).

Unfortunately, it's not without flaws. The controls are very floaty which makes platforming imprecise. The story-telling has its moments but feels a bit shallow at times. Worst of all, because you're tasked with controlling three characters at once, you'll find yourself constantly switching between them and moving them one by one. This gets repetitive very quickly and becomes more of a hassle than anything. Why there was no option to control all three at once is beyond me, but it could've gone a long way towards eliminating the annoying backtracking that hampers the game's pacing.

While the game's significant backtracking/pacing issues keep it from being truly great, The Cave still excels at being a fun and humorous adventure game. One that warrants multiple playthroughs if you hope to experience everything it has to offer.

reviewText:
The Cave is set up like an old-school 2D side-scroller.  Seven adventurers, each with a dark past, go down into a magical cave in a journey of self discovery.  At the beginning of the game (which is narrated throughout by The Cave itself), you choose three of the seven advernturers and descend.  Each section of The Cave is a puzzle that requires your three characters to work together.  Three of the sections are uniquely designed (by the sentient Cave) for the characters you've chosen.  In this way, The Cave encourages you to play though multiple times.

The drawback is that there's also three generic puzzle sections which you cannot skip.  I'm on my second playthrough, and while it's nice that the game shuffles the order of the puzzles, it can be a drag to re-solve old puzzles to get to new content.  And the achievements require you to play through the game... I don't know how many times, but I imagine The Cave's jokes (while clever) will start to wear thin on the fifth playthrough.  If you really want to get 100% achievements, you might consider reviewing the achievement list online before you play, despite the mild spoilers.

I'd still recommend this game - the humor, art and story make this puzzle game very enjoyable and encourage multiple playthroughs.  May get monotonous if you're looking for all the achievements.

A definite buy if it's on sale.

The Cave is a Double Fine adventure game looking like it's trying to be one of the old Lucas Arts titles back in the 90's with promise of witty writing and a unique gaming experience with each play through.

The game allows you to pick three of the seven characters available and use your team to explore the deepest part of the cave each with their own story but the characters you pick have no personality, do not speak,  do not interact with the other players and are only used as ways to access a specific dungeon that tells a small story to said characters.

The Cave works on a linear level like progression where each part has one main puzzle and each puzzle plays out the same, collect certain items that each character can hold only one of . Use Item A on mechanism B to open the next area. This would not be so bad if you did not have to control three separate characters at one time to pick up only one item and having to traverse a platform -esque dungeon to get to the other side, trying to micromanage where each player must be using some poor platforming and slow movements.

One of the biggest turn offs to the game is once your first run through is completed you get to go through the game again with another three players but the dungeons and puzzles all stay the same apart from the characters cave segment but with seven characters this means you will have to play the game three times with the last run through having players you have already played before! These short slideshow endings are most definitely not worth it.
The dialogue is mildly entertaining, limited and delivered mostly by the narration which  does repeat itself on each replay.

The game has a lot of charm and character but these alone will not hold up next to poorly implemented game design, mechanics and for a title that is trying to encourage replayabillity it comes off incredibly shallow.

1) Essential purchase

The ghosts of spelunkers past
Ron Gilbert is an industry legend. Having grown up with so many of his games as a young child it was partly thanks to Mr. Gilbert (amongst other icons from the era) that my love for the medium  blossomed continuing right through to my teens and eventually adulthood. Maniac Mansion was the very first computer game I ever bought with the pocket monies I had earned from doing odd jobs around the family house and I cherished it (although I never completed it nor got very far into it - this being the days of pre-internet where walkthroughs, hints and lets play's were distant and  unimaginable realities). Thanks to a little series known as Monkey Island, featuring an intrepid wanna-be pirate hero named Guybrush Threepwood, Gilbert's name would forever be etched into the far recesses of my game-loving mind and by default become a cause for celebration when releasing something new.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=388072415
The Cave, Ron Gilberts latest adventure creation, carries the DNA of both Maniac Mansion and Monkey Island in its veins. Where as his previous game, the Deathspank series, grew tiresome very quickly thanks to a titular hero that loved the sound of his own dumb voice as he rattled off one bad pun or joke too many, The Cave is ghoulishly funny. The Caves core mechanic should be instantly recognizable to anyone who has played Maniac Mansion. Offering seven characters from which you can choose any three to take on a spelunking adventure will determine the kind of adventure you will experience. Each one of the seven characters: an adventurer, scientist, monk, time-traveler, knight, set of twins and hillbilly have their own grim tale for you to uncover by exploring areas of the cave unique to them. Choose the knight and you will need to get the blessing of  marriage from a wayward king's daughters in order to retrieve a sword set in stone or choose the time-traveler and you will encounter a future where you will be required to decode its past in order to unlock its secrets.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=388071977
Desire and greed are the motivating factors that drives each of these characters forward whether that be the twins plotting to murder their strict no-fun loving Victorian parents or a scientist hellbent on unleashing an atomic bomb into the world despite repeated efforts by npc's and the games narrator that doing so would be catastrophic. Each characters story arc acts as a darkly morbid cautionary tale and for the most part it's funny in a way that elicits giggles even when each character you choose is committing duplicitous acts in order to achieve their wants and needs.

The Cave plays out like a side-scrolling platformer with adventure/puzzle solving elements and sadly this is where the game struggles to make a lasting impression. Controls are fiddly and many of the puzzles you encounter will require excessive backtracking in order to complete. The Cave also overuses a certain mechanic - the dragging of crates and boxes in order to move the game forward - and it's this overuse that ends up making it feel a bit uninspired and generic in the puzzle solving department. While some of the incorporated puzzles are clever and require some out of the box thinking, too many rely on the lazy mechanic of dragging a box or crate to proceed. The Cave does, however, have a novel approach to replay value because finishing the game with your chosen three characters means you have four more characters each with their own individual areas within the cave to explore.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=388070985
Gilberts black humor does shine through The Cave even when some of the characters selfish tales lack the desired bite that accompanies the darkest of humor. As you progress through The Cave you will need to uncover each characters back-story by unlocking fragments from their past that are hidden deep within the cave itself and it's a pity that each characters tale is uncovered with as little fan-fare as possible. Static background drawings depicting a scene from the life and times of each characters is all you get. It would have been nice to have the narrator, who is the voice of the cave, recount each characters past which would have in turn added more gravitas to their greedy, selfish natures as we witness their slow undoings.

The Cave attempts to teach its players lessons about the nature of greed and letting one's desires run rampant without a care or thought for others but most of this stuff should already be apparent to all except the heartless, psychotic and pathological of you out there and as a throwback it's an interesting mix of old and new. As a game, The Cave is a bit of a mixed bag that never truly settles into its own identity but even Gilbert on a good (although not great) day is better than no Gilbert at all and while not all of The Cave comes together as planned it still offers up enough juicy adventure gaming goodness to warrant a purchase.

The Cave is such a mixed bag I'm honestly not sure if I can give it a recommendation or not. I was equally frustrated by the game for as much as it charmed me.

The Cave is a hybrid point-and-click adventure paired with the mechanics of a platformer. You're given a choice of seven characters to choose from (An Adventurer, Knight, Scientist, Time-Traveler, Hillbilly, pair of Twins, and Monk), each of which can change the journey of your playthrough.

The art design of the game is lovely and the voice work is doubly so. It has that Monkey Island charm that Ron Gilbert is so well-known for and it shows through the many humorous spouts of dialogue from the narrator and various people you meet in the cave. There are lots of little touches that will please even the most picky of gamers and it's in my opinion that the charm of this game is easily one of its strongest components.

The objective of the game is to discover the backstories of each character through a series of illustrations unlocked by finding symbols on the walls of the cave. At the start of each game you select 3 characters to journey through the cave with, each with a unique level attributed to them. Some are fun, such as the Knight's level in-which you steal an amulet from a dragon and end up destroying the kingdom in the process, but some are just tedious, such as the Adventurer's level, filled with puzzles that give you no indication of how to solve them. Along the way you play through each character's origin story which involves puzzle solving, block pushing, item-using, and so on. It's just such a shame that the endings of each character (of which there are two for each), only involve still pictures and no sort of interactive elements. reviewText:
The Cave is a narrative driven puzzle-platforming game where players pick among 7 unlikely heroes that couldn't be more different.

The game at first glance is very decieving, it's called 'The Cave' and you pick 3 characters out of 7 as you descend into the cave but it's not about spelubking or exploring caverns. Instead, you are uncovering each character's history and story. The cave somehow transforms into each of the characters stories as you progress through the game. Individual story set-pieces if you will.

It's a puzzle-platforming adventure game at heart so this means you will be switching between characters and backtracking quite a bit. It does get tiring sometimes and without the backtracking, the game would be much shorter than it already is. Climbing ladders (there's lots of them) becomes a chore and jumping down from higher places only to watch your character fall to their death becomes quite tedious.

The 7 characters include: A knight, a hillbilly, a scientist, a time traveller, a monk, an adventurer, and a set of twins which counts as one. You'll probably play the game 2 times to get 6 of the character's stories but to get the 7th you would have to play the game the third time and you may not think it's worth it unless you really like the game.

Pros  Interactive narrator
Double Fine Productions' signature brand of comedy
7 Characters, each with their own ability
Sense of adventure
Full controller support
Cons  Short campaign
After you finish the game with all characters, there's no reason to go back
Most puzzles are way too easy
Linear level designs, one way to progress, one way to do things
Supports local co-op but not recommended since the camera only follows one character
More to interact with would have been nice
Final Thoughts:
I actually like the game but just because I like it, doesn't mean it will be everyone else's cup of tea. It will only appeal to some people. I expected something different but it didn't turn out too bad. Shame that it's so easy and so short. It's a good puzzle-platformer but it could have been better. I admit that I like it as a big fan of Double Fine Productions but there are alot of competitors in this space.

Rating (6.5 out of 10)

reviewText:
This game is pretty bold in its mix of traditional point and click adventure aspects and jump and run mechanics. You choose 3 out of 7 characters, who all come with their unique abilities, background story and areas. You move around by climbing ladders and ropes. There are common areas where you need all three characters to solve the puzzles and specific character areas that need the respective character's ability to be solved.

The puzzles are stupidly hard, I played this game with my partner, and we couldn't of finished it without the aid of the walkthrough. You would need some very critical thinking in order to get past the second level without some sort of guide.

As this was my partners first proper PC game she had played, apart from Sims and WoW, I think it did a very good job of introducing different game mechanics for people who haven't even played this sort of game before.

This title is not very linear, which will catch many modern gamers by surprise, who are used to heavy handed scripted playing. The humor is dark and entertaining, so are the individual stories behind the characters. The art and mood is amazing in here too.

The annoying part of the game is that you often at times have to walk back and forth to solve puzzles, which is compounded by the fact that you sometimes need to move three characters to a specific location. A character summon function would have been handy here. But that doesn't ruin an excellent gaming experience for a low price.

I hope the younger gamers will appreciate it despite the lack of heavy scripting from newer games. We both thoroughly enjoyed the game, but like I said, without the aid of a walkthrough, I fear there may of been an argument at times at deciding which way to do the puzzle!

reviewText:
The Cave is a fun, enjoyable adventure, but it has a few flaws.

Let us begin with the good things it has to offer. It has a good sense of humor, even though some of it is hit-and-miss. It also does a decent job at managing the multiple stories. You'll be playing with 3 (out of 7) characters at the same time, all with their own story. As a result there's also a bit of replay value there for those who absolutely enjoyed it all the way through.

And while I liked it there were still a few things that bothered me. The first and most obvious are the blurry graphics. Yes, it uses a certain style, but it was still below my expectations. It's nothing groundbreaking, not as a game or an engine, so I expected better here. The characters are well animated though. It reminded me of something... I can't quite put my finger on it. But I do know is that I've seen this animation style before.

The puzzles are actually pretty decent and require some thinking. I had to use a walkthrough more than once. You see, I'm not that bright ;) And except for The Walking Dead (which isn't really a traditional adventure anyway), (point-and-click) adventures usually aren't my cup of tea.
So forgive me if I say that I won't be playing it again with any of the other characters. One playthrough was more than enough for me. Like I said, it's a good game, but nothing extraordinary.

But, you might have an other opinion if you're a die hard adventure player, of course. I myself expected better from a studio that brought us the brilliant Brutal Legend, Psychonauts, Stacking and Costume Quest. You're better off playing any one of those.

This game is still very much worth a play.

reviewText:
I'm more of a point-and-click adventure fan myself, but The Cave's platformer-adventure system works well. There are no tasking platforming elements, which is great since there is quite a bit of backtracking involved. The puzzles are simple and amount to little more than scouring the area for items whose purpose is usually easy to sort out, or arranging your characters so that they 'work together' to solve a puzzle. This generally means that most of the game's content is in travelling and taking in the sights rather than elaborate puzzles and dialogue trees, which is good only if you're expecting this.

There are two main highlights for me: the narration by the Cave itself, and the surprisingly dark storylines of each of the 7 characters. The characters themselves have subtle personality, even though they don't have any dialogue. Each character's area is well designed and wonderful to experience, and made me want to play through each person's story.

I'd recommend this game for people who enjoy a slower paced game, who like to soak in atmosphere and interesting stories, and who aren't looking for a particularly difficult challenge.

reviewText:
An adventure! In a cave! This game is a cross between a point-and-click adventure game and a side-scrolling platform game, with the focus on the former. You pick your three adventurers from a choice of seven and then into the cave you go to solve puzzles and have some laughs along the way.

The Cave is a talking cave and is voiced well, but doesn't talk as much as I'd like, and I found the solutions to some of the puzzles to be rather obtuse. Occasionally I got stuck and had to read a walk-through guide to figure out how to continue. At times it was annoying having to control three characters because I had to move them all separately which was pretty boring.

But the graphics and animation are good, and the audio is also good. And there were a few genuine LOL moments in the game. It's just a shame the puzzle solving and game-play were a little weak, but I hope the game was successful and that a bigger, better and bolder sequel will come out.

There's a little replay value as the different characters you choose give you a slightly different path through the cave, but most sections remain the same regardless of your choice of characters.

Overall, 7 out of 10.

reviewText:
What seems to start out as a simple puzzle game with influences from old classics like Maniac Mansion and the Lost Vikings actually ends up being something very unique and intriguing.

You pick three characters from a cast of seven to enter a bizarre talking cave in search of something the characters desire. You solve puzzles to progress through each area, which are closest in style to a point 'n' click. They range from very simple to relatively puzzling, but generally you can figure each one out with a few minutes of lateral thinking. If you're stuck, there's plenty of guides out there too.

The heart of this game isn't about the puzzles, however. The quirky, dark humour and the metaphor that emerges as you delve deeper drive you forward. The Cave is more than just a puzzle game, it holds a message that moves the game closer to being a piece of art.

reviewText:
It's  a fun adventure game but not really to the same level that I expect from Double Fine for a few reasons.

First off, it may seem like a small thing but I think it's annoying that there's 7 main characters but you can only do 3 per playthrough. This means that you can have 2 completely unique playthroughs, but then if you want to see the 7th character's storyline you'll have to do a third playthrough with mostly repeated content.

Second, I feel like this game would have benefitted from more voice acting, although I understand this might have been due to budget restrictions, but if it was a stylistic choice then I just don't get it.

The characters you play as are supposed to have these big dark backstories that you uncover, but there's never any opportunities to show their personalities, even when I was playing as particular characters I felt like the story that was being revealed was for NPCs not the characters I was controlling. I think this could have been showed off more through voice acting.

However, the game is still very charming. You're led through the game by The Cave itself, an omniscient narrator who has a dry sense of humor as he details all of your experiences. It's actually pretty fun. In addition, there's quite a lot to like about many of the levels, especially the ones that are specific to certain characters. The hillbilly's carnival level in particular was  a lot of fun.

The games not very challenging. If you're paying attention most puzzles are pretty easy. However, there are certain parts that seem to drag on.

It's definitely not perfect, but overall I think it's a decent game, although the writing isn't quite up to what I expect from Double Fine.

reviewText:
The Cave on one level is a really enjoyable game, I really  like the graphic style, general game play, puzzles, the variety of different characters & their stories, and that each character has a unique ability, meaning different areas can be solved in different ways depending on who is in your team, and their own area of the cave to solve/explore, which adds to re-playability.

On the down side the controls can be iffy and annoying. For example the characters jump several seconds AFTER you hit the jump button, and they will often run on after you release the arrow key (so if you want/need them to stand in an exact location, forget the keyboard and just use the mouse).

This can make certain puzzles a struggle too, since even after you've worked out what to do, actually completing the puzzle is made even more difficult due to the above control issue, and on several areas where you have to do a lot of difficult jumping and climbing make one mistake and you have to do the entire puzzle all over again, the under/over reactive controls can be adjusted to, but still make some areas a lot harder than they should be.

That said this game has plenty of charm, character, a good re playability value, and the narration can be genuinely funny. The controls may work better with a controller rather than the keyboard (I haven't got one to test it out). . Flawed but  I would still recommend this game

reviewText:
The puzzles in this game are not all that bad - they are in fact the game's one *and only* strength.

On the other hand, the puzzles could have been a lot better - they could have been designed with multiple solutions using various character specific abilities that would make you feel really clever to figure out the different ways to solve them. They could have, but they didn't. What a waste.

When there were multiple solutions, they too were just lame. There's one point where the scientist can use her 1337 hacking skillz to open a door... or, you could just pull the lever right next to it. Another where the Adventurer can grapple over a pit of spikes... that she could have just jumped over. When you can do something profoundly different (like using the Monk's telekinesis to obtain a guarded item early, or carry an extra hotdog with you for 3/4 of the game to shortcut a later puzzle), it felt more like an exploit of a poorly thought out level design rather than something sneaky you could do as a deliberate design decision by the writer.

The writing in this game is just bad - it's clearly trying to be funny, but I don't think I even smiled once while playing, and I certainly didn't laugh. The Cave is sentient and provides a narrative voice, but the voice actor simply reads the jokes off the script in an almost monotonic voice with no emotion whatsoever. The other voice actors aren't much better, but really the problem is that the script is just lame and didn't really give them any room to shine.

The story reminds me of the type of work I'd have submitted for high school English (if not worse) - in my mind I could create really interesting characters, with a dark unsettling past that I'd put together in an unusual and interesting setting and have some event spiral out of control of the characters, bringing their best and worst traits out as they had to reluctantly work together to overcome... yeah, what I wrote on the paper was little more than a Star Trek rip off.

I can tell that in the writers mind he had developed seven really interesting characters with a dark past that are going to commit some terrible atrocity in the cave - unfortunately the game fails to develop any kind of connection to the characters and we feel absolutely nothing for the characters and no remorse for the evil deed that they do.

I'm not nuking the Earth as the Scientist because the game has developed a connection with her and I can see that she believes that it is really her last option to eliminate an oppressive government that only pretends to listen to it's intellectuals as a facade so they can continue pretending that planting a few trees will solve climate change and that dumping three million cubic metres of mining dredge spoil on the Great Barrier Reef won't have any adverse affects (spoiler: it's not actually that interesting, she just wants money).

No, I'm simply turning the three launch keys because it's the only way the game will let me progress.

The game has good & bad endings for each of the characters, but they boil down to a single choice at the end of the game to take a souvenir (bad ending), or return it to the gift shop (good ending) - that's just lame (as are the chalkboard endings), and it doesn't even let you save before the decision to see the other ending without playing through the entire game AGAIN (MINIMUM FIVE PLAYTHROUGHS TO SEE ALL THE ENDINGS - what a waste of time). Oh, wow, do I love this game. It reminds me of the kinds of games I grew up with as a child and played over and over again until I could do them perfectly. . . The problem with not having all that much money but having way too much time on my hands as a child. That's first world problems for you.

I'm not going to say it's for everyone, though. The humor is rather dry and often at least a little bit macabre (the twins, for instance) but if you like dark humor (which I love) this game will at least be fun for that.

There are a few problems. There are some odd glitches every now and again, though they are not all that frequent (unless you're doing the no deaths runthrough, when every deadly glitch rears its ugly head). The biggest problem is that you can't skip any of the cutscenes or dialogue. Don't get me wrong, both are superb in this game (I'm pretty sure Grey DeLisle voices at least one of them, too) but since this is a game that relies on multiple playthroughs, the skip feature really should have been included. I mean, trying to do the no deaths playthrough alone will probably have you just leaving the room on occasion to do other things while you wait.

Saying all that, this game is just too much fun to pass up. It's worth the price and if it's on sale, doubly so. Oh, and get the soundtrack because it is fantastic!

(Also, I just checked, and Grey actually voices three characters.)

The artstyle and music are phenominal. The platforming itself is great but could use a little work, especially when compared to how well games like Mario control.
Each of the seven characters are unique and interesting, as are their specific challenges. You will want to play through this game more than once just so you can experience all of the characters and collect their cave paintings and endings.

For each character there is one specific dungeon, along with each of those three unique dungeons there are four mandatory dungeons that must be completed in every playthrough regardless of the characters you are using. The four mandatory dungeons are the gift shop [extremely tedious], the mines [extremely tedious], the zoo [a little tedious (can be skipped by bringing a hotdog from the gift shop)], and the island [pretty tedious].

reviewText:
The Cave is a cute little game made by DoubleFine. It is a side scroller point&click, the controls are legacy of both genres and you will have no problem getting into it whether you are more comfortable with one or the other genre.

I personally like Point&Clicks and the idea of The Cave in general, everything is fine, descent ambiance, good story-telling (Stunning narrator voice).

The game is built around several characters, you will choose three characters for each of your run, and go through The Cave that will lead to different path depending on which characters you choose.

The problem is that half of a The Cave run is the same, regardless of which character you choose. The number of character available isn't a multiple of three (That means that you will have to go through the path of two characters two times). That completely breaks apart the idea of a replayable game, because you basically have to go through the same content several time to get the new content (Which is annoying and pointless in a point & click game, it's a repetitive mindboggling grind).

If you have the time and patience (I am usually really patient, and I have a lot of time for games, though I hadn't enough) You will probably enjoy all the content of the game, and be really happy with it. If you don't, the game will only offer the third of what you paid for.

This is a great game, you should definitely check it out if you get the chance. I'm not saying you should go out and buy this right now, because it does have its fair share of problems.

The artstyle and music are phenominal. The platforming itself is great but could use a little work, especially when compared to how well games like Mario control.
Each of the seven characters are unique and interesting, as are their specific challenges. You will want to play through this game more than once just so you can experience all of the characters and collect their cave paintings and endings.

This leads into where the game comes up short. It was meant to be replayed but has little replay value. The four mandatory dungeons are the gift shop [extremely tedious], the mines [extremely tedious], the zoo [a little tedious (can be skipped by bringing a hotdog from the gift shop)], and the island [pretty tedious].

Here is how you complete the gift shop (tutorial) dungeon so you know what I'm talking about: Walk all the way to the end, grab a crank, walk all the way back, use crank on well, grab bucket, walk all the way to the end, place bucket, grab fuse, walk all the way back, place fuse, grab hotdog, walk all the way to the end, place hotdog, with a second character grab fuse, walk all the way to the end, replace fuse.

reviewText:
Many, if not all, cultural phenomena can be traced back successfully to a point of origin, something that Hunter S. Thompson would call a “long fine flash“ condensing the energy of an entire generation, ushering forward the new and unexpected. For adventure games that point was late 80s and the reason was Ron Gilbert with his crew at LucasArts. When the team was busy laying the foundations of an entire genre with Maniac Mansion, my parents were still enjoying a carefree and childless life so, unfortunately, I have missed what some consider the golden era of point-and-click adventure games. Even later on, my path has rarely crossed with the classics, being a primarily console gamer and all, but finally the genre has caught up to me and sparked my interest like not many do (maybe it was the top hat). Finally, upon seeing the trailer for The Cave, the title that Ron Gilbert was returning to adventure games, I knew that fate was giving me a chance to confront the past of the genre and maybe even the future. After finishing the game I’m pretty sure I saw neither.

The game starts with the player being greeted by the titular Cave, who will also be the narrator further on, and being given a choice of 3 out of 7 distinct characters with vague names such as The Scientist, The Adventurer, The Monk and so on. Each of the characters not only has a unique ability to them but also an exclusive storyline. Quite soon you will realize that the narration is something different from what we are accustomed to – none of the characters, except the Cave, have any dialogue and their past is discovered by the player in comic book-like pages that are plastered on the walls with an occasional nod or hint from the omniscient narrator. The Cave offers a rather rarely seen exposition by gameplay where you unravel the mysteries by your own actions – and most of them are not what would be generally considered “nice”. You accidentally murder people on your quest to get the treasure, push the switch or any other achievement-trope you can think off which generates an unique feeling of dread of what will the next area and next puzzle bring. The pinnacle of suspense is by far the campaign for The Twins, which presents us with two children determined to break away from their over-loving parents – at all costs (think of Tim Burton when his creative juices were still running). It is easy to spoil what happens in The Cave so I will not go into further details as the stories presented are not exactly complex, yet they somehow latch on to you, as every parable should.

The gameplay is broken into 6 areas – 3 unique to their characters interwoven with 3 more general with everybody in your team taking part in the action. As you go further down, the spelunking will take you from an old mine through a monster-infested route up to an isolated island whose only residents are an old hermit, his parrot and his dog (hilarity ensues). The puzzles contained within the sectors, while not very creative or fresh, flow naturally from one to another and very rarely do you feel like your path is being artificially blocked. When you leave the island you have seen the worst side of your back-stabbing, money-grubbing, fame-craving team and you are ready for a catharsis, a moment where you can make all wrongs into rights and somehow redeem your ensemble. Unfortunately, you are thrown to the entrance of the Cave where you uncover the last page of the comic book. The game ends.

With 4 hours on the clock you feel cheated, not only by the game time (you still have other characters to play after all) but by the lack of resolution. After all you have went through, it feels like the game-creators have thrown the towel in mid-sentence and called it quits, leaving the player yearning for a proper ending to a story they have witnessed. With each next playthrough the feeling only intensifies. Once again you are forced to complete the same general areas which offer nothing new – not in terms of cooperation which boils down to “have three people pull three levers” and not in terms of using unique abilities to solve puzzles. The platforming, with which the game is abounded, is stiff and rather annoying, not surprising given Gilbert's detest of it. You begin to long for a normal inventory instead of going to-and-fro carrying items one at a time. The character-specific areas feel wonderful and refreshing but once again the crew’s struggles feel futile in the wake of the ending. Even the addition of a “good” ending that can be achieved is meaningless, as it feels tacked on and irritatingly un-final.

When you look back on The Cave you see an unpolished gem that, with a bit more work and thought put into it, might be seen as an example of proper gameplay-driven narrative dealing with common, but not trivial, themes. It is a journey that does as much well as it does bad leaving the player with a thirst for more. As for my dilemma – unfortunately it is neither the past nor the future but the present, in all it’s wobbly, uncertain and disappointing glory.

As enticing as another double fine game made by the same person who brought you Maniac mansion sounds, I would only recomend this to people who are completly starved for another adventure game. You can take control of a group of three quite unique and well desighned characters from a pool of seven as you lead them to face their dark secrets and gain the one thing they truely desire.

The problem with this game come in three factors. One, while the characters look interesting at first glance. you quickly realize that the only view into what make them up is literaly a seven page comic that you find pieces of alonge the way. None of them will say anything about the things and events around them which is a heavy staple in any adventure game. Having differnt people observe the same places that you have to go through every playthough in seperat ways would drastically cut down on the monotonus parts of this game which leads to...

Factor number two which is that several of the puzzles while clever are hanpered by long hallway and slow ladders seperating each puzzle piece. This is also compounded by the fact that each member of your group can only carry one item at a time neccesitating constant back and forth even well you do find out what to do. One play through was hard enough which leads to.....

Factor number three which is that if you want to get all of the ending comic panels you HAVE to play the game from start to end SIX TIMES. you have seven people to play as each with a good and bad ending which is decided by one final choice and a hidden one at that. Also you would think that playing as new people would change the game drastically but eachs person's dark deed moment is sectioned off into a different stage. I could see which ones I was missing as I passed the themed enterance down the cave.

It pains me to pick this game to pieces because I really wanted this to be good. It had a good consept from under used genre. I was even reminded of a lighthearted silent hill as wierd as that sounds because both are about people with dark pasts venturing into a location that changes itself to force that dark secret into the person's face, But it's held back by bad use of the three person mechanic, shallow characters, and tedious puzzles.

reviewText: It isn't great, to be honest. The game has a handful or fairly interesting stories to tell, but the gameplay itself is just a mess. This is a platformer game that wants you to control three characters at a time to move through various puzzles and situations - and each character has their own unique power that helps them with puzzles. While that sounds fun, the problem is that each of the character's abilities are more or less irrelevant.\n\nThe game is broken up into areas where you have all three of your characters at your disposal - where non of your abilities matter and you're really just playing as one character and annoyingly dragging the other two along for the ride - or you're playing sections meant specifically for one of your individual characters that is suited to their unique power. These sections really don't make up for the others in creativity or enjoyment - they're fairly dull gameplay wise through and through. This game is really about the story, which I generally don't mind at all - but with games like that, the gameplay really has to either supplement the story or get out of the way. The problem with The Cave is that the gameplay isn't just in the way, but it is really just a chore to slog through for anyone with basic platforming skills. Your final product is a game with a few good stories with a lot of not fun stuff in the way of them. This game sounds fun on paper, but I wouldn't let that fool you - The Cave never meets its potential and will likely leave you sometimes bored, sometimes frustrated, and mostly underwhelmed.

The Cave is less of a full fledged adventure game and more of a compartmentalized adventure game. You choose 3 of 7 characters to enter the cave and each character will have their own puzzle level with 3 constant puzzle levels that the player must always play through.

For the old school adventure aficionados, the Cave won't be a challenge and may not live up to the experiences of games such as Monkey Island. For the rest the Cave sits as an enjoyable puzzle game with simple control schemes and interesting puzzle levels.

There are 7 total characters each with a different special ability, the only issue I have with the abilities is that most of them are really only used in their specific levels, otherwise some of the abilities are pretty useless through out the rest of the game. There are characters that will allow you to get through certain puzzles quicker than normal but no puzzle requires a character outside of the main character for that story. Each character has their own story to tell, mostly told through their own level as well as through the storyboards that you pick up throughout the game.

Due to only being able to play 3 characters at a time, multiple playthroughs of the game are needed to see everyone's ending. This only causes problems when you have to play the default puzzles that always show up in the game. It would have been better if there was say 6 default puzzles and 3 random ones would be dropped in everytime you played to keep the player guessing as to which puzzle was next. I got bored of the default puzzles real quick after playthrough 5 and up.

The main dialogue in the game comes from the Cave itself and is really well written. Sure you'll get bored of it after playing through the game several times but on first play through it's enjoyable to listen to.

The Cave is an adventure game worth playing but don't come in expecting it to replicate the old school adventure games.

reviewText:
Not even on a Steam Sale

First the good stuff: Art and character design

This game has a whimsical art style and can be a fun cross between puzzles and light platforming, with particularly funny narration and character design.

The bad stuff: Poorly executed forcing of replay

The game punishes users for indulging in that whimsy. The game forces painfully slow backtracking as you figure out a puzzle. Funnily enough, what's worse is when you can't backtrack: Because you frequently pass points of no return accidentally and the game autosaves, you can't have fun exploring an area you've completed because you risk losing access to collectibles or missable achievements. If that is a part of gaming you enjoy, it pretty much forces you to play with a guide open to keep you from missing anything, completely devaluing the collectibles and achievements.

However the most aggregious, avoidable design sin is tha for each playthrough you select 3 out of 7 characters (I'll say it again: Three) to take through the campaign, which changes three character specific levels to the game. Did you catch that? The selection of three out of seven? If you are going to obligate replays like this, why not have a number of playable characters that is divisible by three!? This is infuriating and since several puzzles in the cave are permenant fixtures, not character specific, this means you have to play through some puzzles 3 times, and other puzzles (for the two characters you'll play twice) 2 times. Getting all achievements demands a total of 5 playthroughs, but by then you'll have lost all interest.

There are some great indie-like titles on Steam, I encourage you to find them instead of buying this one, regardless of the price.

reviewText: pay no attention to the critics, THE CAVE is a very funny and genuinely entertaining game, regardless of its minor flaws. if you've ever enjoyed playing any of the earlier lucasarts games or anything in the more recent double fine catalogue, this is a no brainer.  no, it is not super long and yes, some of the puzzles are a bit frustrating when coupled with the (very)  few minor bugs that are scattered throughout the game, but the overall work that went into the whole thing is apparent from the start and even the weirdest puzzles can not detract the quality of the game as a whole.  it's got a very goofy and cynical sense of humor with a couple of laugh out loud moments mixed in between several absurdly over the top scenarios that we've come to expect from double fine, although this time they cater especially towards those of us who have much more mischievous (and possibly misanthropic) inclinations.  the replay value is actually somewhat high and there are several really funny achievements that are worth going after because it simply highlights the attention to detail that was put into each of the 7 character's unique sections.  on a scale of 1 to using precious fossil fuels to power a hummer, i'd give this game 3 and half thumbs up.

Before I get into my complaints about this game, I just want to make it clear that I did, overall, really enjoy playing this game and would happily buy the sequel if they ever get around to making one.  The game play reminded me a lot of the old Vikings games, minus the perma-deaths, where you had to rely on the abilities of more than one person to get a job done.  The character levels and the “transition” levels (those stages usually between the character specific ones) were pretty fun and the puzzles, while not that hard, did give my brain a little exercise.     I won’t even bother gush over the art style or script for this game because you’d have to be made of stone not to like them.

This all being said, I did have a few problems with it.  First off, seven was not the lucky number here, it should have been nine.  The reason for this is that, by the time you get to the third round of the game, you have now exhausted playing all but a single character.  This means you have to repeat at least two people’s levels.  Knowing exactly what to do makes for a less fun experience the second or third time around.  I say “third time around” because of my second complaint.  I would have loved to see this game provide more than three “transition” stages.  Again, the ideal number would have been nine.  If the game designers had given each character their own transitional stage, then you would have never felt like you were playing the same game twice.  Tedium is the worst enemy of the “one solution only” adventure game.  If you have already solved the puzzle once, what value is there in solving it exactly the same way again?

Of course, even after saying that, I would still recommend this game to anyone who wants an excuse to laugh and enjoy a few hours running around a sentient cave.  Just remember, sometimes your greatest desires can be your own worst enemy.

Before I get into my complaints about this game, I just want to make it clear that I did, overall, really enjoy playing this game and would happily buy the sequel if they ever get around to making one.  The game play reminded me a lot of the old Vikings games, minus the perma-deaths, where you had to rely on the abilities of more than one person to get a job done.  The character levels and the “transition” levels (those stages usually between the character specific ones) were pretty fun and the puzzles, while not that hard, did give my brain a little exercise.     I won’t even bother gush over the art style or script for this game because you’d have to be made of stone not to like them.

This all being said, I did have a few problems with it.  First off, seven was not the lucky number here, it should have been nine.  The reason for this is that, by the time you get to the third round of the game, you have now exhausted playing all but a single character.  This means you have to repeat at least two people’s levels.  Knowing exactly what to do makes for a less fun experience the second or third time around.  I say “third time around” because of my second complaint.  I would have loved to see this game provide more than three “transition” stages.  Again, the ideal number would have been nine.  If the game designers had given each character their own transitional stage, then you would have never felt like you were playing the same game twice.  Tedium is the worst enemy of the “one solution only” adventure game.  If you have already solved the puzzle once, what value is there in solving it exactly the same way again?

Of course, even after saying that, I would still recommend this game to anyone who wants an excuse to laugh and enjoy a few hours running around a sentient cave.  Just remember, sometimes your greatest desires can be your own worst enemy.

The Cave is a beautiful basically point-and-click adventure with a side order of platforming. The music and controls are okay. But the main thing are the stories of the set of characters three of which you choose for an adventure in and narrated by The Cave.

+ Interesting stories and good narration
+ Nice elevator-music-like background music
+ Multiple adventures through The Cave with almost no feeling of repetition
+ Mostly good controls, controller recommended
-- Missing button to start a new game when in a game
- Mostly unskippable cut-scenes and no fast-forwarding for text
- Walking doesn't save you from walking over edges
- Inconsistent Time Traveller controls
- Dropping stuff when quitting Cave Paintings
- Some glitches

At the start of the game you basically choose your adventure by selecting three out of seven characters. Each of the seven characters has their own 1 (and a bit) story which, connected by some sort of communal stories, is narrated by The Cave and supported by Cave Paintings.
During those stories you travel through The Cave and have to solve basically self-contained puzzles in a point-and-click fashion, although this works well with a controller, where each character can carry at most one item. The music is not to memorable but is in no way off-putting.
Although the game encourages multiple play-throughs you can avoid the feeling of repetition by coming up with a number of different approaches after the first encounter, some of them seriously reducing the time for specific parts.

In the context of achievements I found the controls somewhat lacking. Their is a do-not-die achievement that would seriously benefit if the walking mechanic also prevented chars from walking over edges. Instead characters have sort of roll-out phase which may well let you walk into the next pit and death. This nuisance was aggravated by the facts that 1. there is now way to start a new game without first quitting the game altogether, restarting it from steam, then choose and confirm you want to start a new game; and 2. cut-scenes are mostly unskippable. That's a strange thing games sometimes do. If a player has seen that cut-scene five times in the last hour they may actually know it well enough. Anyway the player should simply be able to decide whether to skip or not.

Some minor gripes:
* When leaving Cave Paintings the character sometimes drops the item they are holding.
* The Time Traveller can basically travel over, not stand on, water, except sometimes that doesn't work.
* The Adventurer can swing through the first lever gate when it's half open.
* On top of the Island the Cave Painting sometimes doesn't show.

Overall, what sells The Cave are the stories and the way they are narrated. Additionally it's interesting to come up with short-cuts through the game. Apart from the missing restart mechanic and mandatory cut-scenes I seriously enjoyed The Cave and thus recommend it,

I didn't buy The Cave immediately when it was originally released and this is mainly because I'm not a Ron Gilbert, Tim Schafer, or Double Fine fanboy. I like all of those things, but the only Ron Gilbert game I ever played was Maniac Mansion (which was great, but I was like 8 years old), and both Tim Schafer and Double Fine have shown me that they can do as much bad as good sometimes (cough ... Brutal Legend .. cough). I did eventually acquire The Cave though and having finally played it, found I enjoyed it.

Right up front, the presentation of this game is top notch. The art, controls (I used an Xbox controller), and sound were excellent. The core conceit of the game design (choosing 3 out of 7 characters to go through the cave) I felt was a bit lacking though. The game makes concessions for your not having certain characters (and their abilities) with you and with the exception of completely optional cave painting unlocks and very minor shortcuts, your choice of characters is purely narrative. This isn't horrible, but it means you'll have to play through the game 3 times to get all the character stories and content, repeating the non-character specific areas of the game each time.

The actual control of the multiple characters works rather well and for the most part the puzzles designed to rely on them are interesting as opposed to frustrating. My one gripe with the controlling multiple characters is the backtracking that takes place for each one in many instances. While there are checkpoint-like locations where the two other characters will instantly appear at the side of your controlled character in order to alleviate the tedium of treading the same ground again, some puzzles still require going back and forth through the same area with two or more characters in order to solve a puzzle.

In the end, The Cave is a pleasant blend of adventure and puzzle genres with what I would consider to be an entry-level to intermediate difficulty. What it may lack in complexity it makes up for in charm and I'd recommend it if you're looking for a mild puzzler with good personality.

It is a puzzle solving game that reminds of the old Monkey Island days.

The Cave, which is the main character, serves as a guide as you explore its depths. There are 7 different characters to play with, each with his/her own abilities and backgrounds. You must choose 3 of them and enter the cave to discover their true nature, and help them cooperate to survive.

The game is handled with a very good, and dark, sense of humor, and alternative paths depend on what characters you pick, adding replayability.

The game is very well done, and there are very clever puzzles in it. Well, we should not expect less from Ron Gilbert. The drawings are amazing, and the designers paid great attention to details. The music and sounds are simple but add a lot to the experience, and the voice acting is top notch.

I did not give 5 stars because the game itself is very short. Moreover, even when playing with a new set of characters, there are parts of the cave that are repetitive. Maybe if they had done more sections that could be played by all characters and made them appear randomly, it would have added a lot of replay value, and would have made it more fun to try to get everyone through.

Target audience: Casual players. It is too easy for hardcore gamers, though it can be enjoyed by anyone.

This was an enjoyable play.

Graphics are well done and narrative is humourous & whimsical. Although there are times where dialogue with in-game characters can get annoying when you're running back and forth trying to figure things out.

Puzzles were unique and challenging. However, the time travel level, I found, was a little far fetched so it took me a while (and some hints) to get through that one. There were some levels too, that became monotonous & time consuming due to backtracking by having not chosen the appropriate character for a particular task or just simply trying to find clues on what you needed to do.

I do like the fact you had to choose the character best suited to solve a particular part of the puzzle and that you can get through the most levels with whichever 3 characters you choose. Some levels aren't available if you don't have the characters to get through them, but you can always go back and replay with new characters - which is nice.

All in all, I would definitely recommend playing. It was fun!

Maniac Mansion creator Ron Gilbert returns with an all-new point-and-click adventure about three people (selected from a cast of seven) seeking their hearts' desires in the depths of a mysterious, magical cave. That talks.

A hilarious game from start to finish, albeit a bit short. As with Maniac Mansion, much of the replay value comes from learning how to combine each character's unique skills to reach the end, but each of the characters also have their own story (generally involving heinous deeds) that is revealed piece by piece along the way.

If you can get it on sale, The Cave is definitely worth a try.
